channel.title: Welcome Page on Santi's Index Card System
channel.description: Recent content in Welcome Page on Santi's Index Card System

item.title: Subtraction Instead Of Addition
item.description: Whenever you are creating something, weather it’s: writing, video editing, drawing or any form of creation keep this in mind: Less is more. Make removing the fluff into a habit. No piece of art was achieved in the first try. Perfection (or something close to it) is usually found in subtraction not addition. Think of sculpture, where the artist removes the rock to find his masterpiece. Think like a sculptor.

item.title: Fear-Setting
item.description: Defining your fears and understanding them, can be more important than setting goals. It will help us act on what we fear most. Sources Tim Ferriss’ Fear-Setting Exercise Heed your fears Derek Sivers Themes Entrepreneurship Mental and Psychological Exercises

item.title: Storytelling Creator
item.description: As your audience we don’t want to just see the end result of your efforts. We want to see your struggle, your ability to overcome adversity. Show me what’s happening behind the scenes, show me your doubts. I’ll see you as the human being you are and I’ll relate more to you. Invite us to see your hero’s journey. Sources seanwes (I need to find the post where I saw a similar idea, perhaps it was in Instagram)

item.title: The Value Of Ideas
item.description: It’s not just ideas that matter, it’s how they make us feel. We often hear the classic: “Ideas have no value unless you execute on them." This makes sense from a monetary stand point, but ideas have the power to bring us joy, energy and life, if that isn’t meaningful I don’t know what is. Learn to respect your ideas for the inherent value that they have. Execute on the best ones, but don’t look down on the ones you don’t act on.

item.title: Fear and Excitement
item.description: It’s the combination and excitement that determines when something is worth pursing. Excitement by itself is not sufficient, Fear by itself might be something we are afraid to do, but it’s not even something that will give us the benefits we seek. It’s in the combination of both of these that we find what we must do. Sources Instagram Ruben Chavez Think Grow…On Fear and Excitement Themes Entrepreneurship Connections How To Be An Entrepreneur

item.title: Internal Success
item.description: Turning success into something internal, to develop an internal confidence that goes beyond external recognition. Not to need anything outside ourselves to call our lives a success. Sources Ego is the Enemy Themes Entrepreneurship Connections How To Be An Entrepreneur

item.title: Beautiful meaning
item.description: Be u to full be you to full be you to the fullest Sources Source: minute 33:12 Laurel Airica // Word Magic: The Power of Language, Spellcasting & Recreating the World Themes Words

item.title: Metonymy
item.description: Definition of metonymy Metonymy plural metonymies. Men are trash, sounds as if saying all men are trash. When we attribute a concept to a large group. It’s a dangerous generalization without much consideration. Dictionary: “A figure of speech consisting of the use of the name of one thing for that of another of which it is an attribute or with which it is associated (such as “crown” in “lands belonging to the crown”)”

item.title: Phronesis vs Sophia in Greek
item.description: Practical knowledge vs Sophia wisdom.

item.title: Character
item.description: Character Character is the ability to keep going even after the initial rush of excitement has passed. This relates to the idea of quitting and persisting. It’s difficult to know when we should keep going and when to be wise enough to quit. Quitting is not an act of weakness, quitting can be a great idea when we realize we are not moving forward to where we want to go.

item.title: Dignity
item.description: Dignity means to be worthy of. Themes Words Connections Worthy of Recognition Character

item.title: Worthy of Recognition
item.description: Not to strive to be admired by others. Not to strive for being recognized of our efforts, but to let our work and our contribution be worthy of recognition, even if we never get it. Sources Brian Johnson Nobody Wants to Read Your Shit by Steven Pressfield Connections Dignity

item.title: No Problem is Permanent
item.description: No problem is permanent. We might feel as if our current circumstances will last forever, we must trust in the fact that it will soon pass. Connections ‘Problem’: Meaning

item.title: 'Problem': Meaning
item.description: The word problem comes from the Greek. ‘to throw forward.’ It is called a pro…blem, it is a positive not a negative. It’s not a con…blem. Sources Problems Vs Conblems YouTube Themes Words Connections No Problem Is Permanent

item.title: Text Editors
item.description: As much as all of us trust in programs such as Microsoft Word, pages and note taking apps. We must understand something important if we care about preserving our work throughout the years. When a new version of an application updates, old files become difficult to read, they must be converted to be accessed. If the company you trust decides to make your old files obsolete, it will mean a lot of work in order for you to save them, worst casenario you will lose them.

item.title: Translating Ideas Into Our Own Words
item.description: Note-taking requieres us to read something and translate it into our own words. To take what we’ve read and processing it. We must consider it’s relevance to our own work or or lives and do our best do understand it. Notes are not a tool that makes writing easier, they make it doable. Book Ch: 2.0 How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens Zeigarnik Effect Overcoming It With A Simple Trick

item.title: Non-Specialist Panic
item.description: Perhaps I can call this non-specialist panic. When you freak out for the apparent lack of direction you have compared to someone who is a successful specialist. Connections multipotentialite

item.title: Epigram
item.description: Epigrams are short and pithy statements that tend to involve sarcasm or humor. Sources Wikipedia Epigram Sources Themes Connections Aphorism

item.title: Multipotentialite Definition
item.description: Some people are born with a personality more prone to have several interest, several passions, and sometimes even the inavility to focus on just one passion for an extended period of time. These people are described by a variety of names the most common one is Jack of All Trades. They are also described as scanners, polymaths or multipotentialite. Sources Terminology - Puttylike Book: Refuse to Choose Themes Words Connections Beneficial Beliefs

item.title: How To Be An Entrepreneur
item.description: To create our own brand successfully the formula is simple but of course not easy: To be authentic, finding a way to match our interests with what society wants. Then we must leverage our work, through connecting with others and finding a way to reach an audience. Putting our name on it, this means we will take the risks but you get the rewards by taking ownership of our work.

item.title: Chicken Eagle
item.description: The story of the eagle who was born amongst chickens and never tried to fly like the eagles he admired. He lived and died convinced of his self imposed limitations. Counter argument to staying humble… Sources Prince Ea: FORGET YOUR NEW YEARS RESOLUTION Connections Dangers of Ambition Icarus on Not Flying Too Low

item.title: Icarus on Not Flying Too Low
item.description: Icarus story and the dangers of flying too high, yet also the dangers of flying too low. Sources Prince Ea: FORGET YOUR NEW YEARS RESOLUTION Connections Chicken Eagle

item.title: NASA Pen Story Is False
item.description: The famous story of NASA zero gravity pen NASA Pen Story, is great. Unfortunately the story is not true. The people at NASA are not that dumb. They where fully aware of the pencil as an alternative. It turns out that pencils are dangerously flammable in space. If the tip breaks and gets lost in the spaceship it can cause serious problems. Paul C. Fisher developed the zero gravity pen which was approved by NASA and used in space.

item.title: Philosophy
item.description: Themes

item.title: Philosophy Is Everywhere
item.description: You can do philosophy in any field, in any particular interest. Sources My interview with guest: Michael Tremblay. “#38 -The Art of Becoming A Stoic (With Michael Tremblay)” Themes Stoicism Philosophy Connections

item.title: Stoicism
item.description: Themes

item.title: Story Of Astronaut's Perspective
item.description: Perspective from space Source: Stillness is the key, chapter All is One. In 1971 the astronaut Edgar Mitchell saw the planet from a distance of over 350,000 km (217.000 miles) and felt an overwhelming sense of connection, this is the place where all suffering and joy comes from. Write about pale blue dot related writings of my own perspective from space on our suffering 200220 Write on Another Earth’s story of the sound clicking

item.title: Truth
item.description: Themes

item.title: Truth Tony DeMello
item.description: No one can tell you the truth. Those who claim to know it are lying. All anyone can do is show you falsehoods. All anyone can do is show you what takes you further from the truth, by avoiding falsehoods we get closer to the truth. Most of it requieres unlearning the social brain washing we are all subjects to, unlearn something every day and you will be closer to wisdom.

item.title: One Must Imagine Sisyphus Happy
Personal Thoughts
item.description: Themes

item.title: The Introvert Dilemma
item.description: When you are feeling particularly introverted there’s something about people that often becomes stressful. You hang out with someone once, and before you know it they’ve planned how you’ll spend the next 5 years of every weekend together with you. This is the introvert’s fear, and often the reason why we have to think twice before committing to hang out with someone.

item.title: Creating Free Content Vs Marketing Strategy
item.description: There is a difference between the two following ways to operate a business online: Creating free content that attracts the right clients. Creating free content without a plan, to make things sustainable. Number 1 relies on a well thought-out strategy to attract the right people to become part of your business. Number 2 might be a good way to get used to creating, but it’s by no means a business model by itself.

item.title: Entrepreneurship
item.description: Themes

item.title: Follow What's Effortless
item.description: Specially while feeling low or unmotivated, search for the things that call your curiosity. Learn what you feel like learning. When possible don’t force yourself to do things you don’t feel like doing. It’s okay to put certain projects on pause. Connections The Value Of Ideas Clarity Will Pull You Forward Let the Work Carry You Forward

item.title: Presenteeism
item.description: Presenteeism is the act of being present. Usually used in the office. A convention to be at the desk whether actually doing productive work or not. Sources Book: The Multi-Hypen Method Themes Words Connections Creating Free Content Vs Marketing Strategy

item.title: Productivity
item.description: Themes

item.title: Takahashi Method
item.description: A technique that consists of making visual presentations as simple as possible. Sources Takahashi method - Wikipedia “Sent” Presentation Software For Linux.

item.title: Biomimicry
item.description: The art of designing based on nature. Imitating nature’s process to design, create and innovate Sources The world is poorly designed. But copying nature helps. Biomimicry is more than just good design Themes Words Nature Connections Spider Web Notes

item.title: Habits
item.description: Themes

item.title: Habits Sleep
item.description: There are habits that won’t necessarlity make you succesful, but still completely necessary to avoid failure. The best examples is sleep, having enough sleep doesn’t necessarily bring you success by itself, but the lack of sleep can really affect your ability to succeed. Sources 3-2-1: James Clear Newsletter Themes Habits

item.title: Nature
item.description: Themes

item.title: Spider Web Notes
item.description: To organize notes in the structure of a spider web. To create strong lines of ideas that are later connected from the inside and later reinforced. Sources Spider Net Building Timelapse Connections Biomimicry

item.title: Multipotentialite Example Davinci
item.description: One of the most famous and succesful Jack of all Trades we know in history is the great Leonardo DaVinci. DaVinci had an incredible ability to work on an infinite amout of different fields of study, including art, science, arcquitechture, anatomy. The list is so long almost to the extent where you could take a field of study and research on how DaVinci made mayor contributions to it. Connections Multipotentialite Definition

item.title: The Streisand Effect P1
item.description: The wish to hide information that ends up in making it popular. This term is named after Barba Streisand who filed a lawsuit on a photographer taking a drone photo of her home in Malibu in 2005. (Yes, drones already existed). Originally only 6 people have downloaded the photo, after the controversy half a million people shared it online. (Remember this is 2005 so that’s a lot.) The guy who created the the term received a claim from a hotel for taking a photo of a urinal.

item.title: The Streisand Effect P2
item.description: The Steisand Effect is the efforts to hide something only to make it worse. This is a clear example of how our actions backfire when we are not careful. Fighting to get things going our way often end up making things worse. Source: Ryan Holiday Ego Is the Enemy Chapter: Always Love (Last Chapter) Connections The Streisand Effect P1

item.title: The Zeigarnik Effect
item.description: Open tasks occupy more space in our short term memory until they are finished. Unfinished tasks occupy a lot more of our mental energy, compared to finished ones. Example: The story of the waiter who memorized everyone’s orders, but couldn’t recognize someone’s face when they came back to the restaurant for their jacket. Connections Using The Zeigarnik Effect To Our Advantage Zeigarnik Effect Overcoming It With A Simple Trick

item.title: Using The Zeigarnik Effect To Our Advantage
item.description: We can ask ourselves open questions that we will stay in the back of our heads. This concept allows our subconscious to wonder about things we want answered but are difficult to figure out in the moment. Sources Book Ch: 9.5 How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens Connections The Magic Question

item.title: Zeigarnik Effect Overcoming It With A Simple Trick
item.description: Solution: We don’t need to finish everything in order to move forward, all we must do is write it down convincing our brains that it will be dealt with. Breaking things down into manageable steps Break the task of writing into small pieces. Externalize your thoughts and write the connections, so that you can pick up where you left it. Sources Book Ch: 9.5 How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens

item.title: Agrippa's Trilemma Infinite Questioning
item.description: When we make why questions and dig deeper: it will always end up in one of 3 ways: A circular argument, to get trapped in A because of B, B because of A. An endless chain of explanations. Ending on a central concept that can no longer be questioned. Sources 1:36:50 Agrippa’s Trilemma infinite loop of questioning. Themes Analogies, Stories and Terms

item.title: Escalation Of Commitment
item.description: To have a sense of foolish consistency in a behavior that has no benefits. Yet, we find it hard to quit because we feel we’ve already committed and we must stay consistent at all cost. This concept is also known as The sunk cost fallacy (or Concorde fallacy) Sources 7:00 Self Reliance PNTV (beware foolish consistency)

item.title: Minimum Viable Effort
item.description: Minimum Viable Effort What is the bare minimum I can do today, to call today a success? To lower expactions instead of trying to always overwhealm ourselves with more. Sources What is Your Minimum Viable Effort? Themes Productivity Connections

item.title: Pareto Principle
item.description: Aka 80 20 rule. This principle explains that for many things in life 80% of the results we seek come from 20% of our efforts. Themes Laws, principles, effects Connections Minimum Viable Effort

item.title: Six Time Perspectives
item.description: There are six time perspectives: Past-negative Past-positive Present-fatalistic Present-hedonistic Future Transcendental-future Sources Derek’s summary of book Time Paradox Overview of Time Perspective Types Themes Analogies, Stories and Terms Connections

item.title: Dunning–Kruger Effect
item.description: This is a cognitive bias where we tend to beleive our abilities to be greater than they actually are. When we struggle to objectively recognize our lack of ability on something. Sources Why You Need to Read Modern Books on Stoicism

item.title: Emotional Intelligence isn't Real
item.description: Emotional Intelligence was invented by a journalist. Sources Source: Jordan Peterson 6:30 Self-esteem Doesn’t Exist

item.title: Iremia Greek Word
item.description: ηρεμία (i̱remía) ηρεμία (i̱remía) Greek Tranquility also translated as serenity. Sources Pronunciation And Meaning Of Tranquility wikipedia i̱remía Themes Words

item.title: Mathew's Principle
item.description: Mathew’s Principle, the bad gets worse. Bad habits causes worse habits. Good habits cause better habits. Inspired by Mathew in the Bible. Sources Source: Jordan Peterson 6:50 The Optimistic Question Themes Laws, Principles, Effects Connections

item.title: Segal's Law
item.description: Segal’s Law states, “A man with a watch knows what time it is. A man with two watches is never sure.” Having too much information can often make a decision more difficult instead of easier. Sources The Big Apple: “A man with one watch knows what time it is; a man with two is… Comments Sivers by Ian Shepherd (2016-04-21) Segal’s Law 15 sec podcast Themes Laws, Principles, Effects

item.title: The Process Of Running Can Be Devided Into 3 Phases
item.description: Cartesian phase Based on Seventeenth century French philosopher, Descartes. Your mind negociating with your body to give up. The Humean phase Based on Seventeenth century Scottish philosopher, David Hume When thoughts appear from nowhere. Sartrean phase based on after the French existentialist philosopher, Jean-Paul Sartre The moment where you surpass reason and enter a rare state of flow. Sources Philosophy of Running (I need to find this blog-post in my archive).

item.title: Aphorism
item.description: These are memorable statements that express a general truth or principle. Sources Wikipedia Aphorism Themes Words Connections Epigram

item.title: Eponymous Laws
item.description: Eponymous is when something is named after a person, place or thing. Common examples of these are: Classic Example is: Murphy’s Law. Sources List of eponymous laws - Wikipedia

item.title: Let the Work Carry You Forward
item.description: In thermochemistry there’s a difference between exergonic and endergonic reaction: Exergonic: You need to keep adding energy to keep the process running. Endergonic: The process continues after it’s been triggered and even generates energy of it’s own. *Being Pulled Rather than Pushing Forward Being pulled forward to do our work through a satisfying process. Sources *Book Chapter 8 (Let the Work Carry You Forward) How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens

item.title: The Magic Question
item.description: The idea is to create open-ended questions that will stay in the back of our head. This can also be referred as direction questions. The idea is to determine something we would like to improve in our lives, it could be internal or external. Examples: Internal: How can I feel more calm today? External: How can I make a million dollars this year? Eventhough it works with external things it’s important to consider what’s in our control.

item.title: Words
item.description: Themes

item.title: Advice, Clarity and Dealing with Contradictions
item.description: Themes

item.title: Being Present
item.description: Not to give up the present for the sake of a dream of an ideal future. Connections Clarity Will Pull You Forward

item.title: Clarity Will Pull You Forward
item.description: Clarity will allow you to be pulled out of bed in the morning. It allows you to be driven to do what fulfills you. Clarity on your vision makes the difference. When you have clarity you don’t need to push through in hard times. During adversity, clarity is the force that pull you to keep going. If you haven’t experience this yet, you probably haven’t figured out your why yet.

item.title: Creative Genius
item.description: The concept of genius comes from the Greeks. Genius wasn’t something that was always attributed to people. People admired artists and innovators, but they didn’t attribute their genius to them. Genius was an external force that inspired them, they were called daemons. Some type of force or even a creature, think of Dobby from Harry Potter. Sources TED TALK Elizabeth Gilbert Your Elusive Creative Genius Themes Ego, Success and Humility

item.title: Live The Questions
item.description: Trust in the fact that what you currently struggle with, cannot be answered right now. To wonder about our flaws as if they were books written in a foreign language, or locked doors. Things we do not understand, but must learn to live with. In our solitude in the understanding of this questions we will eventually reach an answer. These answers cannot be forced, we must learn to live the questions themselves.

item.title: Angel or Muse
item.description: Steven Pressfield calls his source of inspiration The Angels or the Muse. Sources Book: The War of Art Steven Pressfield.

item.title: Counter-Intuitive Humility And Genius
item.description: We can’t say: I’m the most humble person I know it defeats the purpose. Maybe accepting that we’ll never be as humble as we wish we were is a place to start. Ironically that might take me in the direction we seek towards humility (but don’t let ego know, he’ll get all proud and mess things up). Themes Advice, Clarity and Dealing with Contradictions Entrepreneurship Connections Genius and the Ego

item.title: Genius and the Ego
item.description: In Greece artists were thought to have an external genius. Having an external source of inspiration meant that the ego of artists didn’t grow uncontrollably. Their genius wasn’t only theirs. People didn’t praise just them, but also their external genius. Sources Elizabeth Gilbert: Your elusive creative genius | TED Talk Themes Ego, Success and Humility Connections Creative Genius Counter-Intuitive Humility And Genius

item.title: Humble I Don't Know
item.description: When experiencing doubt, overwhelm, contradictions or unanswered questions that conflict me I can start saying: “I don’t know the answer to that, let’s keep living to find out." It trains the muscle of humility, the one that allows us to keep learning from life, instead of believing we can come up with concrete conclusions every time. Themes Ego, Success and Humility Connections Counter-intuitive Humility and genius

item.title: Public Speaking Reading Your Audience
item.description: In order to be good at public speaking one must learn to create a dialogue, to read the audience. To adapt from people’s reactions and be able to present different ideas and know how to make them resonate with people. Sources Jordan Peterson (I need to search for the correct video in my archive.) Themes Connections

item.title: Your Genius Grants Wishes
item.description: The word genius comes from the word genie. Striving to act as a genius has the ability to grant us wishes, but it’s a limited power where one has to wish wisdom and make the proper sacrifices to get it. Sources God Prayer No Wishes Wishes Jordan Peterson Song Connections Creative Genius multipotentialite example DaVinci

item.title: Dangers Of Ambition
item.description: The drive that makes us succeed can quickly become a curse. We might sometimes be fueled by the wish to prove others wrong. This motivation can take us to dark places. It is important to remind ourselves of the limitations of our power, not to fool ourselves with projections of our ego. Themes Ego, Success and Humility Connections Counter-Intuitive Humility And Genius Wanting Credit Not Telling Ourselves Stories Of Our Own Greatness

item.title: Lack Modern Mythology
item.description: With a lack of mythology in our society, we unconsciously attach to the stories that are thrown at us. They might even be harmful such as the story-line of: Consumerism Strive to have more than your neighbor, delay your happiness until you have the material possessions and the luxury you need. Sources Episode 42 Myths Connections Not Telling Ourselves Stories Of Our Own Greatness Our Lives Are Stories

item.title: Not Telling Ourselves Stories Of Our Own Greatness
item.description: Not to tell ourselves stories of own greatness. This feeds the ego. We strive to be able to say in the future. ‘I always knew what was coming, all of my struggleswere part of the plan.’ We need to be more humble than that, not tell ourselves stories of our own greatness. To live in the moment with the humility to recognize how little we know about the outcome of our current actions.

item.title: Our Lives Are Stories
item.description: We are all writing our own stories. We must then ask ourselves: if I where to read this (my life right now) would it be worth reading? If not what calls for adventure am I missing on? What changes can I make? Sources Brian Johnson on Nobody Wants to Read Your Shit by Steven Pressfield. Connections Not Telling Ourselves Stories Of Our Own Greatness

item.title: Wanting Credit
item.description: We might have an urge for control, which might makes us say: ‘Things need to be done my way.’ Often times it doesn’t even matter, but we want the credit and we dread letting others take any credit for our work. Sources Book: Ego Is The Enemy Ryan Holiday Chapter: Entitlement Control Paranoia Connections Dangers of Ambition Counter-intuitive Humility and genius Not Telling Ourselves Stories Of Our Own Greatness

item.title: Anecdotes
item.description: Themes

item.title: Desire Causes Suffering
item.description: The things we desire can often make us weaker and dependant on things outside of our control. Some of these things can be worth pursuing, if we are willing to suffer for them. Yet sometimes we seek comfort just because we are used to it. Connections Involuntary Cold Shower

item.title: Lost Kid In Parking Lot
item.description: I was with my family going to the parking lot after going to the cinema. There was a little kid who seemed to be lost, she couldn’t find her mom. We approached her and asked her. Where’s your mom, are you lost? She said, I’m not lost, I am here, my mom is the one that’s lost. Her mom found her a few seconds after that. That phrase became an inside joke in my family, but I guess she had a point.

item.title: Madness Of The Crowd
item.description: When we are in public we behave in completely different ways when we are in by our selves and when we are surrounded by our friends. The other day I was on a train and this group of loud kids were yelling and being rude. Then 3 out of the 4 kids left the train and the one that was left alone, was quietly and peacefully looking out the window.

item.title: Pull Up Bar Scam
item.description: There is a pull up bar challenge that scammers set in the streets. Hang yourself from this pull bar for 100 seconds and win a 100 dollars. It costed 10 dollars to participate. Instructions suggested that the bar rotated if you move, if you stay still it doesn’t move. This plays with your ego, even though few achieve it, it’s designed for most to fail. Additionally the bar is really thick covered with grease.

item.title: Involuntary Cold Shower
item.description: Yesterday as I was entering the shower. I’ve taken cold showers in the past for a month straight. I developed the will to be able to do it. But yesterday I was really feeling like taking a hot shower. The hot water was working and all was good, but all of the sudden the shower failed and I was running out of hot water. What do you do when you run out of hot water?

item.title: Washing Dishes
item.description: Some things requiere patience, allowing things to take their natural process might make process not only simpler, but much less stressful. Think of times when you are trying to remove a stain while washing dishes. You might start trying really hard to remove the stain. Sometimes all we have to do it allow the stain to soften by the water for some time. We can then return to it and remove it without force.

item.title: Breathing Out To Breath In
item.description: We cannot catch a breath unless we let go of the air we have inside. It’s a sequence. I need to let go off air in order to breath in new air. Sources An awesome thought by my mom. Themes Analogies, Stories and Terms

item.title: Chasing Butterflies
item.description: It’s like chasing a butterfly, the more desperately you chase it, the further you are from getting it. It’s not until you relax and sit down that the butterfly might land on you. Sources Thoreau comic zen pencils Happiness comicbook strips Themes Connections Letting Go Off Effort Analogies, Stories and Terms

item.title: Juggling Idea
item.description: Habits or developing a lifestyle philosophy requires time and practice. Think of juggling. Not only have we not yet developed the muscle memory or coordination, in life our bad habits, not only stop us, but they take us on the opposite direction. Left hand(drops ball to the floor) gradually improves by throwing the ball upwards. dialogue: We can slowly learn how to develop the habits we need. Right Hand (drops ball to the floor)

item.title: Let Die To Let Live
item.description: Let Die To Let Live lyrics from song by Eden. Sources Song: Eden -Sex Connections Breathing Out To Breath In

item.title: Trying to Fall Asleep Forcefully Doesn't Work
item.description: The more you try to fall asleep the further you get from achieving it. It’s only when you let go of effort and calm down that you might fall asleep. Sources Source: Head-space app animation Themes Analogies, Stories and Terms Connections Letting Go Off Effort Let the Work Carry You Forward

item.title: Copyright Piracy and Freedom
item.description: Aaron Swartz lived a tragic life in the fight for freedom of speech in the internet. It’s a complicated and a delicate situation. Sources Source: Aaron Swartz Excerpts Connections Piracy and Showing Your Work

item.title: Piracy and Showing Your Work
item.description: The more people know your work the better. Plagiarism and piracy are not the problem, oscurity is. Piracy can help generate word of mouth. Sources Perennial Seller The Dip -Seth Godin Themes Entrepreneurship Connections How To Be An Entrepreneur

item.title: Day Job
item.description: Thoughts on Day job. Status: Pending Thoughts. Sources Source: Nathan Barry Weatlth Creation CH: When is it worth it to work for a wage? Themes Entrepreneurship Connections How To Be An Entrepreneur Counter-Intuitive Humility And Genius

item.title: Mental and Psychological Exercises
item.description: Themes

item.title: Power of Social media Algorithm
item.description: The most powerful people in the world right now are those who determine the algorithms of social platforms. Sources 1:00:00 Ep1309 - Naval Ravikant Themes Entrepreneurship

item.title: Response To The Past
item.description: The events of the past don’t necessarily make us who we are. What matters more is our response to those events. Connections Six Time Perspectives

item.title: Window Air
item.description: My girlfriend and I have lived in this rented shared house for a few months. The room gets extremely cold at night. There always seems to be a breeze passing through the window. Today was extremely windy. I was going to put tape or something on whatever is causing so much wind to pass through. Today I discovered that at the very top, there’s a hidden plastic thing. You move it in a strange way and you fully block the passage of wind.

item.title: Babies Cry For What They Want
item.description: Babies ask for what they want by making crying noises, screaming or making some random sound. When their parents give them everything without asking an effort from the baby, the baby takes longer to learn to talk. They get complaisant, they thing that making crying noises is enough. They no longer make an effort to learn. Themes Analogies Connections

item.title: Dolphin Names
item.description: Dolphins refer to each other by name. They emit certain sounds to call and identify other dolphins. There have been studies to determine if they have specific words for several things. Due to their high pitch sounds, most of them are not within the human hearing range so it’s difficult to determine. Sources Source: Talk the Talk podcast 161: Conlang 1 Sources How are you? greating what’s your age

item.title: How Are You? Greeting What's Your Age
item.description: Different languages have different way to great. In English we might ask “how are you” we don’t really care about how the person is, it’s just a greeting. In other languages one might say “What is your age” as a form of greeting. This is used because in order to know what pronoun to us one need to know the other person’s age. Sources Source: Talk the Talk 161: Conlang 1

item.title: How To Approach Contradictions
item.description: Changing and improving yesterday’s opinion for better ones is a good form of contradictions. what we must avoid is inconstant beliefs. These are beliefs that stop us from choosing path. They give us paradox of choice. We must avoid being a victim of foolish consistency. This means doing things that no longer make sense to us. Yet we keep doing them because we don’t want to be inconsistent, because that’s how we’ve always done things.

item.title: Inconsistent Beliefs
item.description: When we have several priorities what we must avoid is inconstant believes. This are priorities that contradict each other. Sources Source: My Dissertation Interviews (T) Connections How To Approach Contradictions

item.title: Astronaut Star Sailor
item.description: ástron (ἄστρον), meaning “star”, and nautes (ναύτης), meaning “sailor”. The term comes from fiction stories. Themes Words Sources Wikipedia Astronaut -Terminology

item.title: Beneficial Beliefs
item.description: We have some predetermined beliefs that have been imposed to us from society, friendships, family and culture. A lot of these beliefs can be damaging, or self limiting. Getting rid of them is no easy task. What we must become aware of is that there are an infinite amout of beliefs we can adopt. They take time and consistency in order for them to form part of our identity. The first step is to take a good look at the belief you want to adopt and see how beneficial it will be in your life.

item.title: Make Time By Saying No
item.description: We must learn to free time to gain clarity. We feel guilty about saying no to something we don’t want to do, because we don’t want to hurt the feelings of whoever invited us to do it. We find it easier to tell someone. I can’t do your thing, because I already committed to something else. Instead of. No I don’t want to do that because I’d rather have free time instead.

item.title: Overcoming Contradictions
item.description: We must learn to speak our new truths with conviction, even if it contradicts the past things we’ve said.Otherwise we can be stagnant out of fear of being a hypocrite. Instead it’s better to admit that we didn’t know better. This also means we will probably learn new truths in the future that contradict the our current ones. This is how growing is done. Don’t fear being a hypocrite, if it drives you towards your own growth.

item.title: Reasoning Your Beliefs
item.description: You can reason your way into believing anything you want. You can rationalize anything. Just make sure that the beliefs you choose to adopt about yourself and the world benefit you rather than damage you. Sources Themes Advice, Clarity and Dealing with Contradictions Connections Inconsistent Beliefs Beneficial Beliefs

item.title: Selfishness
item.description: Selfishness Taking control of your own time and saying no to things without guilt is not selfishness. Selfishness is wanting other people to do what we want when we want it. Sources Anthony Demello Awareness Connections Make Time By Saying No

item.title: NASA Pen Story
item.description: The story says that NASA spent a decade and $12 billion to build a ballpoint pen that works without gravity. By 1965, scientist found a way to create such pen with a pressurized ink cartridge and compressed nitrogen. The Russians simply solved this problem by using a pencil. The takeaway is not to over-complicate things, and to look for what’s obvious. Unfortunately, the story is not true, the NASA Pen Story Is False.

item.title: Letting Go Off Effort
item.description: Sometimes we might desperately want to achieve something such as happiness. The more we desperately chase it the more it escapes us. Sources Themes Connections Chasing Butterflies Trying to Fall Asleep Forcefully Doesn’t Work Breathing Out To Breath In
